questions.text: What is the unit of force in the International System of Units (SI)?
questions.explanation: Force is measured in Newtons (N) in the SI system, where 1 N = 1 kg·m/s².

questions.text: Which law states that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant?
questions.explanation: The Law of Conservation of Energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed or transferred.

questions.text: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface?
questions.explanation: The standard value of acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface is approximately 9.8 m/s².

questions.text: If an object has a mass of 10 kg and is subjected to a net force of 50 N, what is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Using Newton's second law (F = ma), acceleration is given by a = F/m = 50/10 = 5 m/s².

questions.text: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity because it has both magnitude and direction.

questions.text: What is the frequency of a wave with a period of 0.2 seconds?
questions.explanation: Frequency (f) is the reciprocal of the period (T), so f = 1/T = 1/0.2 = 5 Hz.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-contact force?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force acts at a distance without physical contact between objects.

questions.text: What is the work done when a force of 20 N moves an object 3 m in the direction of the force?
questions.explanation: Work is calculated as W = F × d, so W = 20 × 3 = 60 J.

questions.text: What is the kinetic energy of an object with a mass of 2 kg moving at a velocity of 3 m/s?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy (KE) is given by KE = 0.5 × m × v² = 0.5 × 2 × 3² = 18 J.

questions.text: Which type of wave does not require a medium to propagate?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves, such as light, can propagate through a vacuum, unlike mechanical waves which require a medium.
